Former Forecast Star Rebuilds Trust, One Grocery Bag at a Time

By the City Bureau | Front Lead

After a televised hail prediction dissolved into blue skies, Arthur Gale left broadcast weather and opened a delivery cooperative from a clawfoot tub with a ledger, two phones, and strict punctuality.

Neighbors now know the operation as Tubline: a punctual, handwritten service for errands that cannot wait. Orders arrive by phone. Routes are plotted in soap pencil on tile. Receipts are clipped to a rubber duck marked “Accounting.”

“Every package gets a forecast and a second knot.”
Continue report

Local pharmacists credit the route with reducing missed refills by 18 percent this quarter. Grocers report fewer abandoned curbside orders. One council aide, speaking off record, called Tubline “our most reliable informal infrastructure.”

Reader FAQ

How do I place an order?

Call the line, state address, item list, and preferred window. A dispatcher confirms total and route number.

Do you carry hot food?

Yes. Soup and tea travel in double wrap. Fried items receive vented tops for texture retention.

Why are reviews only haiku?

Short forms keep the ledger legible and the emotions precise.

Can businesses open an account?

Yes. Bakeries, clinics, and studios can request weekly invoicing and timed multi-stop runs.
